bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, March 3, 1947

div1.p: Truby reviews yellow fever material. He is uncertain about the location of Reed's hospital room and is unsure how often he visited Reed in his final days. He refers Hench to Kean's diary. He identifies persons in the picture and encourages Hench to begin writing his book on Reed and yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, March 3, 1947

opener.dateline:
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, 18, Calif.
March 3, 1947

div1.p:
Well, all of your wonderful pile of material was sent on
March 1st by Express, together with my answers. The whole thing
has been thoroughly enjoyed but it has been almost too much in a
bunch for me to do good work and not get excited. Nothing really
worried me except the huts. That is a mess and you saved the day
by producing that really precious photograph of the huts. That, I
think, really solves everything pretty well. Whoever took that
picture must have done it in 1900, and because he took a special
picture of 118 and 116, I think he knew that those had been the
huts where Lazear and Carroll had been treated. I underscore
Lazear as I really think he had the martyr in mind and so 118 was
in the center of the field.

The only other thing of real importance is about Reed's
early knowledge of Carter's paper and his interest in Finlay's theory.
You have had Lazear in your mind as the leader in the mosquito work
from the start but I have never agreed with you in that. I think my
arguments are sound and I believe General Kean will agree. You may
still find letters of Carter's or Reed's on that subject.

Many of the equestions you asked I have answered before but
I think my answers will not be very different. The location of Reed's
room in the hospital is an example. I have tried to get everything as
near right as possible. While the general situation is quite clear
about most things, details won't come to the surface. While Reed was
sick, for instance, I may have been with him more than one night.
I even may have been in his room the last night for a time, for I
remember all the somberness of the occasion, the location of the bed
and the window. However, I have nothing so good as Kean's diary to
fall back on. Reed was surprised to see me at his bedside. That I
know.

I have just received a letter from General Kean and it is
the keenest and best letter he has written me in a couple of years.
Evidently he is feeling fine and is very cheerful. He is “saving a
bottle of bottled-in-bond to drink to your health” when I come to see
him in May. He says that “Dusty” Siler is now coming along in fine
style after a terrible siege. Good news.'

Before I forget, I want to thank you for the picture of
Reed and his gang with the old ambulance at Camp Lazear. You know I
think that the big fellow with a mustache between Kissinger and Cooke
is Jernegan. The tall chap on the barrel next to Reed may be Springer
- 2 -
and the tall young officer in the dinky cap may have been Kean's
assistant, Contract Surgeon, Peter C. Field. The men in caps sitting
on the ground are Evidintly the Spanish Volunteers, who were there
at the close of the Camp. They are typical Spanish immigrants.
The soldier at the right of Cooke looks like Olsen. All of those
I have mentioned (except Dr. Field) were at the camp in January and
February. This helps in identifying them.
Mrs. Stark might remember Jernegan- Show her that picture and see.

Because of the amount of work, I did not feel like asking
for clerical help from the new C.O. at Letterman, so I did as you
suggested. I could not work very long at one stretch. However, she
- the steno - was very obliging and I paid her $20. I have written
in many things that I found later. I really hunted for things that I
knew were in that Sen. Doc. I always find something new in it. Wonder-
ful book, full of mistakes, but it is grand. How about an index? I am
too busy to do it!!

I called Mrs. Gilhus yesterday about those pictures. She
has not been able to find them but will continue to search. I think
they will turn up in time.

General Kean wrote that he thinks you have now gathered
together all the known facts re the yellow fever story and should soon
get to work on your magnum opus. I agree with him. He and I both
would like to see it in print before the last note of taps fades away
for us.

I am still planning to go to Washington about May 8th and
want to stay a while with my daughter near Frederick, Md. Mrs. Truby
and I want to be East for 2 or 3 months. I want to see you in Washington
in June unless for some unexpected reason we should cancel our trip.

I liked your Brumby and Lambert letters but will return them
later. Would like to know their answers first.

Wish you would let Kean read my typed answers. He may be
able to add an idea here and there that would be of help.

I sent the papers by express as I think
that is sofar and just as easy for me.

I will await your reaction to my effort
with the hope that you won't feel that I
am an obstinate old crank- I can't
change my convictions-

With best wishes for you & Mrs Hench from
all the Trubys.
